description: From Middle English wrien, from Old English wrīġian (“to go, turn, twist, bend, strive, struggle, press forward, endeavor, venture”), from Proto-Germanic *wrigōną (“to wriggle”), from Proto-Indo-European *wreyḱ- (“to turn, wrap, tie”), from *wer- (“to turn, bend”). Compare awry, wriggle.

adjectives.description: wry (comparative wrier or wryer, superlative wriest or wryest)

entries.meaning: Turned away, contorted (of the face or body).
Dryly humorous; sardonic or bitterly ironic.
Deviating from the right direction; misdirected; out of place.
examples: . . . the wry rigour of our neighbours, who never take up an old idea without some extravagance in its application.

verbs.description: wry (third-person singular simple present wries, present participle wrying, simple past and past participle wried)

entries.meaning: (obsolete, intransitive) To turn (away); to swerve or deviate.
examples: God pricketh them of his great goodness still. And the grief of this great pang pincheth them at the heart, and of wickedness they wry away.

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To divert; to cause to turn away.
(transitive) To twist or contort (the body, face, etc.).

description: From Middle English wryen, wrien, wreon, wrihen, from Old English wrēon (“to cover, clothe, envelop”), from Proto-West Germanic *wrīhan, from Proto-Germanic *wrīhaną (“to wrap, cover”), from Proto-Indo-European *wreyḱ- (“to turn, wrap, tie”), from *wer- (“to turn, bend”).

verbs.description: wry (third-person singular simple present wries, present participle wrying, simple past and past participle wried)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To cover; clothe; cover up; cloak; hide.
